unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Two-Proportion $Z$-Test Risks
question_text:
In a survey done in a small town last year, $8$ out of $12$ randomly selected people said they approve of the job the mayor is doing.
The following year, $10$ different people are randomly surveyed, and of these, only $6\text{ people}$ approve.
Why would it be inappropriate to perform a two-proportion $Z$-test to determine whether the mayorâ€™s approval rating has changed?

choices.text: It is illogical to perform an inferential procedure like a two-proportion $Z$-test when the population data is already known.
The data does not come from simple random samples.
The populations are most likely NOT at least $10$ times each sample.

At least one of the following is not at least 5:
${N}_{1}\cdot \text{(pooled p)}$
${N}_{2}\cdot \text{(pooled p) }$
${N}_{1}\cdot \text{(1-pooled p) }$
$ {N}_{2}\cdot \text{(1-pooled p)}$
The combined sample sizes are only $22$, which is too small.
